socalsupermoto Blog

General ramblings of socal supermoto

Independent review Vanson Supermoto suit

For an independent review of the vanson supermoto suit I loaned my to trackday regular Luiz. Well he used to be a regular. Now he can barely ride his wr250x without falling over. Plus he speaks funny Brazilian, so take this all w…ith a grain of salt…

The AlpineStar supermoto suit was my original choice of leathers mostly due to the obvious upright cut, the lack of a road race style back brace (which prevents the Leatt brace from fitting in), and of course because it had ’supermoto’ in the name. But it does come with a pretty gnarly price tag! I’ve tried a number of other suits, none of which I felt comfortable in when sitting on my Yamaha wr250x.

Last weekend I had a buddy tag along with me to the track, who got hooked into supermoto as soon as he saw the bikes on the track. But he did not have gear, so Brian was kind enough to lend me his custom tailored suit so I could look good, and hopefully shave some seconds off my lap times!

Though the Vanson was slightly larger than my A-Stars, it fit pretty nicely. The upright fit was super comfortable for my riding style, and the Leatt brace fit snugly, the way I like it. A noticeable difference is the knee padding, which is not included in the A-stars suit. Instead, the A-Stars have a larger knee area so you can fit your own knee guards underneath the leathers, which is honestly quiet uncomfortable and rather difficult to fit into. Although the knee pads in Brian’s suit were not super heavy-duty, I think it’s plenty protection for most crash scenarios.

In conclusion, Brian’s suit was such a good natural fit, that I did not even remember it was not my own. I had a great track day, and most importantly I felt very safe, which is the most critical aspect to getting good fast laps. I would most definitely consider this suit when time comes for a wardrobe change!

Vanson Supermoto suit

- Upright cut, super comfortable, great fit for supermoto
- Compatible with Leatt and other neck braces
- Knee padding, not the best, but definitely very comfortable
- Easy to get in and out of
- Super nice heavy duty zippers can be handled with gloves on
- No extra space for your own knee protection
- Overall, I like it!

Brian’s edit: I’d add hand made in the USA, lifetime repairs, super comfy, and just generally bad ass.
www.vansonleathers.com

We screwed up.

And it wouldn’t be the first time. We left moty design off the list of supporters for the Paul Lima benefit. They donated one of their very cool and insanely light lithium batteries. We’ve been flogging these for 2.5 years, and I’ll NEVER go back to a standard battery.

Free money (kinda)

I wanted to throw out a plug for our sponsor/friend Hector Urias at statefarm. I called him up to get a quote simply because he was a friend, and then I was floored when he immediately saved me $500 over my geico motorcycle policy. So give him a ring, it’ll only take a couple of minutes and my guess is he’ll save you a bunch of money.

Hector Urias

Evening/night school is this Sunday

Amazing sunset riding and cooler temps makes for the coolest (literally) trackday of the summer. Our school is sold out but if you have a bike please come out and join us. This day is highly recommended. Bikes only, so we plan to run both supermoto and asphalt only sessions. It’s been a few weeks since our last trackday (been surfing) so I can’t wait to get out there and ride!

Vanson Followup – Crash review

A big highside, and lowslide, dislocated shoulder, 24hr hospital stay due to rung bell, and a couple of sprained ankles. It hasn’t been the best year but it could have been worse. Figured now was a good time to do a followup on the Vanson.

Overall I absolutely love it. It doesn’t fit perfect but close, I love the added peace of mind of 1pc leathers (especially mid corner on the highspeed sweeper), it breaths amazingly, and you can really move around without feeling restricted. A favorite feature is the double zip in the front that allows you to cool down between sessions without climbing out of the arms. The 1pc design isn’t as handy as a 2pc between sessions, but then you don’t have do deal with zipping the suit together, or worrying about mid section roadrash if you skip that part. I like how the lower suit is mostly textile under the boot which makes it fit more comfortably, and makes your boot less stanky vs normal leathers. I dig the simple functional design.

Crash #1: I lost the rear and had a 3rd gear, 35mph highside on the big bank turn at adams. I was wearing sidi crossfires, vanson supermoto suite, omega neck brace, and arai vx pro helmet. Honestly I don’t remember the day, much less the crash, so details of the actual crash will be lacking. Nobody saw it, they just came around and found me off the track up by the hay bales.I sprained my ankle, and rung my bell well enough that my memory was only good for 2 min at a time. My friends had a good time making up stories for the 50 times I asked “what happened?” So although I don’t know how I hit it’s pretty clear that I rag dolled off the bike. I had zero injuries from my neck to my ankles. In other words the suit did what it was supposed to do: held up and protected me. The pads stayed where they were supposed to, and I didn’t have a bruise on my body to speak of despite getting tossed pretty far.

Crash #2: In the dirt section I grabbed a touch too much front brake in the dirt and slammed hard onto my elbows, while lower body got trapped under the bike. Not one of those fun lowside where you are already low enough that you just slide it out. More like a good quick body slam. Again another sprained ankle but nothing too heavy. It is the kind of crash that can shift armor pretty easily. Again everything did it’s job.

Overall I’m thrilled to have a suit that is comfy, does it’s job, and will last forever. After years of experimenting with different gear I no longer have to worry about what I’m going to wear at a trackday or for a canyon ride, or wether it’s going to last or do it’s job. I also know that a 10 year old vanson looks the same as a new one, so I don’t have to worry about looking retro in a bad way at the track 15 years from now (only have to worry about looking like storm trooper). As far as “dressing for the crash, I’m covered. Me and my vanson are in for the long haul.

July 20, 2012 | 3 Comments »

Leatt Coolit Vest under Leathers Review

To cut to the chase, does it work? Yep. Read on for more details.

I tested the leatt coolit vest two days this week at Adams motorsports park in Riverside, 15 min riding sessions in 97 degree heat wearing a 1pc vanson supermoto suit. Even though the vanson vents well, at near 100 degrees you need all the help you can get in the cooling dept.

You ever see jet lag pills? They work like this: The directions say to take a pill with 8oz of water every half hour. So they work, you won’t feel jet lagged, mostly because you just drank 8 oz of water every half hour over your 14hr flight. The leatt absolutely works, but I was worried the only real reason it works is because it puts you into the routine of regularly soaking it in ice water then putting it on and off. So I put that exact question to the test.

Vest worn over underarmor: I put on my underarmor shirt, then the vest that was soaked in ice water, and stood around with my leathers on for 10 min, then rode a 15 min session. It did it’s job, It kept me pretty comfortable during the session, but the big advantage is the awesome job cooling your core right at the begining. So it works amazing if you are willing to take it on and off and resoak it every half hour. Instead I preferred to wear my long sleeve under amor first, give the vest a good ice soaking in the morning, then every few sessions with the vest still on pour icy water under the vest. Almost as effective as resoaking, and it was lot easier than taking it on and off. This way you could basically just wear it all day, and just occasionally dump some water on yourself.

Vest worn agaist chest, no underarmor: It may have cooled moderately better, but it was so tough to pull my sweaty arms out of my leathers after the session that it’s not worth it. For MX might be different but for sportbike trackdays and supermoto I’d keep using your underarmor in conjunction with the vest, and again just pour ice water down between sessions.

Icy wet tshirt: To compare how much the cooling was a result of the leatt coolit vest, and how much was the result of just dipping it over and over again in ice water, I did the same routine with a tshirt. I used a american apparel socal supermoto t, which besides its awesome cooling powers, is good for 3-4hp. It worked for a session. I didn’t get steamed to death which was the theory of my riding mates. But frankly the wet tshirt feels super creepy after 15min.

Once out of the leathers, when I was out on the track taking photos of riders, I preferred to take the vest off and just use the underarmor, even with the heat. feels a little heavy and weird, however I never noticed that when geared up. it loosens it up with water, so buy it tight. I wear a xl jacket, large tshirt, and the medium vest fits perfect.

Summary: It works, but requires either resoaking it every half hour, or the cheater soak which is refreshing the cool by pouring water down between the vest and underarmor shirt. I’ll have it in my gear bag, and since I bring a cooler anyway, I’ll absolutely use this on a scorcher day.

Ride it all

The true joy for riding supermoto for me is doing it all at the same time. One corner you’ll be hacking it in foot out, the next sweeper dragging knee, and then slide around the dirt section and jump!

| No Comments »

Paul Lima Benefit – June 24, 2012

Paul Lima Benefit Trackday + BBQ – Come on out!

Paul Lima Benefit – June 24, 2012

Adams Motorsports Park

Riverside, CA. 9am – 5pm. All Welcome!

Our friend Paul Lima, owner of GP Motorcycles in San Diego, fractured his back in a motocross accident. As a result he is paralyzed in both legs. We’ve put this benefit together to raise some funds to help the family, and to show our support. Come on out for a great cause and a great time!

Info on Paul and donation link: http://www.limafamilyrecoveryfund.com/donate.html

Here’s what we’ll have! All proceeds to benefit the Lima family.

  • Mini moto, Supermoto, and go karts welcome! $50 to come ride.
  • Socal Supermoto school – Learn to ride supermoto, $199 for bike, training, trackfees and photography. www.socalsupermoto.com
  • Spectators welcome! $20 and includes free bbq by damn dummy racing.
  • Raffle! Amazing prizes including Jackets, gloves, AGV helmet, lithium battery, gift certificates, etc…Details below
  • Free pro clinic by Silent H himself Gary Trachy!!!
  • Silent Auction
  • Free action photography.

Please help spread the word (shops, facebook, forums) and come join us. All welcome!

Raffle items – Thank you to the sponsors!

The following donations will be available as raffle prizes or as silent auction. Click on any picture to go to the sponsors site.

Socal Supermoto, errr us, will be donating all the proceeds from the supermoto school that day (6 spots). Only $199 for bike, training, trackfees and photography. Just reply to this email to book.

Damn Dummy racing will be providing the BBQ that day

Pro Supermoto rider/owner Silent H supermoto school Gary Trachy will be providing a FREE pro riding clinic!

San Diego BMW Motorcycles has donated a Klim Jacket and BMW (gaerne) GS boots!

Many more small prizes as well. Please mark your calendar now, June 24, for the motorcycle event of the year (Yes even better than motogp at Laguna!)
